text: We use Notion and add a table with all of our marketing movements with the date, owner, status and type (which area of marketing team). Then we add calendar and timeline views so we can visualize what's happening. My favorite aspect is that we also have this big table linked to smaller ones for each "type" so I can see my content calendar, the YT team can see what videos they have coming up, community team can see the events, etc. It's not too hard to set up and everything is organized really well!

text: <@U017WRJTKF1> thanks for your response! I think that's marketing that makes you think of a brand and see people behind it, not just a big corporate body. For example, Semrush's Twitter is so relatable and personalised. But I'm still forming my own ideas about this, so I'm very interested in your thoughts even if they don't align with mine.

text: A big part of strongDM's marketing and recruitment strategy is featuring "meet the team" content on their blog and they do a good job linking the interviews back to their value prop as an org. They also feature a wide variety of faces and voices in their product demo/walkthrough content and webinars, so it feels like a small, intimate organization. Full disclosure - I write some content for them, but I particularly admire how vast their content marketing strategy is.

Happy to give more details if you need them!

text:
Hey everyone, I’m curious to know what are some best practices when coming across an informative piece that’s relevant for your brand?

Do you normally share the link (which just brings traffic /attention back to them) repurpose it as social media content tagging the source or do you gain inspiration and create a blog from it, referencing them?

For context, the company I work for focuses on HR, so my go-to sources are Gallup/HR reporter.

They have a lot of informative articles on HR trends/insights that cater to our audience. Since I’m a one-woman show who oversees/writes all the content, I don’t have the mental headspace to write a blog post every time I see a relevant piece.

What best pratices would you recommend?

Thanks :)

elements.text:
Hey everyone, I’m curious to know what are some best practices when coming across an informative piece that’s relevant for your brand?

Do you normally share the link (which just brings traffic /attention back to them) repurpose it as social media content tagging the source or do you gain inspiration and create a blog from it, referencing them?

For context, the company I work for focuses on HR, so my go-to sources are Gallup/HR reporter.

They have a lot of informative articles on HR trends/insights that cater to our audience. Since I’m a one-woman show who oversees/writes all the content, I don’t have the mental headspace to write a blog post every time I see a relevant piece.

What best pratices would you recommend?

Thanks :)

text: You could consider doing a weekly/monthly roundup post of your favorite articles, with a key takeaway from each to add your brand’s voice and perspective.  And I’d suggest tagging the author (not just the publication) of the article when you share them on social, to help build awareness of your brand with the reporters or thought leaders important to the industry.

elements.text: You could consider doing a weekly/monthly roundup post of your favorite articles, with a key takeaway from each to add your brand’s voice and perspective.  And I’d suggest tagging the author (not just the publication) of the article when you share them on social, to help build awareness of your brand with the reporters or thought leaders important to the industry.

text: The most popular way I see this done is to include "What we're reading" links in a newsletter (if you have one)

text:
Hi all - would love to hear advice on *personas,* especially with B2B buyers*.* How do you establish personas? How do you iterate on them over time as the business evolves? What research and data do you incorporate in the developing process?

For context, we're revamping our personas to reflect evolving business priorities, and it'd be helpful to hear about proven practices with defining + empathizing with buyers, both existing ones and new ones to come. So far, I've started lining up customer interviews across several key industries and roles to hear more about their challenges and needs.

text:
Interviews are a super valuable resource. I think it can be even more valuable to sit in on other meetings with customers — being able to hear their questions, read body language, etc. can reveal concerns more effectively than interviews. I know that having the marketing person sit in on a non-marketing meeting can be a hard sell, but if there's ever an opportunity where it's not awkward I would jump on it.

Depending on the industry, buying third-party research can also be a useful way to understand trends at scale. I am lucky to work in "B2G" (business to government) where there are outlets that publish some high-quality persona research that has been super valuable for me especially in terms of ad spend, media buying, etc.

elements.text:

text:
Calling all podcasters! I run a podcast for Shopify called <https://open.spotify.com/show/01nOz8LFIoZcM34XDPEEgW|In Conversation with Shopify Plus>, where we speak with big-name founder/CEO business types.

*I'm curious how marketers here that may be involved in branded company podcasts measure ROI.* That is to say, "When factoring in costs including production and any paid ad promotion, what is a reasonable cost/listen number to spit out at the end?"

I've Googled my brains out on this, only to come up with every permutation of answer under the sun, so I thought a little crowd-sourcing here would be valuable.

Does anyone use a target cost/listen metric? What might you consider "good" vs. "bad" in the cost to acquire listeners? Any numbers to share in your own experience? Many thanks in advance :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Calling all podcasters! I run a podcast for Shopify called
In Conversation with Shopify Plus
, where we speak with big-name founder/CEO business types.
I'm curious how marketers here that may be involved in branded company podcasts measure ROI.

That is to say, "When factoring in costs including production and any paid ad promotion, what is a reasonable cost/listen number to spit out at the end?"

I've Googled my brains out on this, only to come up with every permutation of answer under the sun, so I thought a little crowd-sourcing here would be valuable.

Does anyone use a target cost/listen metric? What might you consider "good" vs. "bad" in the cost to acquire listeners? Any numbers to share in your own experience? Many thanks in advance

text:
<@U0325G1PXFV>, hi :wave: and thanks, <@U01G7PRL3HQ>.
I focus on interviews, surveys, social listening, and digital intelligence analysis.

We look at what questions the company has internally and then how we can best find those answers externally.

I segment according to jobs to be done. What "job" has the person bought the product for? Those become the segments.

In B2B, I also like to know their:
Roles
Relationships
Responsibilities
Rituals

And other key information like buying triggers, buying motivation, tech stack, and workflow.

Iterating on personas can be done consistently (like one phone call a week, surveys at particular UX points) or intermittently (before a product launch, before a new campaign etc)

I hope that helps!

and thanks,

Rituals

And other key information like buying triggers, buying motivation, tech stack, and workflow.

Iterating on personas can be done consistently (like one phone call a week, surveys at particular UX points) or intermittently (before a product launch, before a new campaign etc)

I hope that helps!

text:
I asked my head data scientist here at <http://Falkon.ai|Falkon.ai> about number 1 because we help businesses track this kind of thing.

He said: Look at things like how many leads/accounts are generating first touches or first touches in a long time from the content to start (since it will take a while for the actual deals to take shape). From there you will want to start looking at how velocity between stages change when engaging with content -- ideally using some form of attribution to determine which leads and contacts were most impacted

text: Ah, gotcha. Yeah, there’s definitely a threshold. For me, the main takeaway after a few months working at an analytics company is that human assumptions can often be wrong! So any kind of rigor around data to assign credit can help challenge our own assumptions about what actually works.

text: <@U01P13NTGG6> with start date and dependencies in Asana - have you found a way to make a template with dependencies that will autopopulate subtask due dates based on start date or due date?  I haven’t been able to figure that out, so it seems like you have to manually enter due dates for all subtasks each time.  Would love to know if you’ve found a workaround!

elements.text: with start date and dependencies in Asana - have you found a way to make a template with dependencies that will autopopulate subtask due dates based on start date or due date?  I haven’t been able to figure that out, so it seems like you have to manually enter due dates for all subtasks each time.  Would love to know if you’ve found a workaround!

text: I believe task templates can do this. They have the ability to have relative start date and end dates (e.g. starts x days after creation and is due y days after creation). However, the subtasks have to be a part of the task template for that to work I think. Though, they did recently add the ability for rules to create subtasks as well (but I’m not sure if those rules would support relative dates).
